entries.meaning: A place from which something can be viewed.
examples: Perched on the edge of the cliff was a hidden outlook.

entries.meaning: The view from such a place.
An attitude or point of view.
examples: Synonyms: attitude, opinion, perspective, point of view, vantage point, viewpoint
He has a positive outlook on life.
The outlook for temperature rises is worrying.

verbs.description: outlook (third-person singular simple present outlooks, present participle outlooking, simple past and past participle outlooked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic, literary) To face or look in an outward direction.
(transitive, archaic) To look at (someone) so long or intently that they look away; to win or prevail over (someone or something).
examples: Synonyms: outstare, face down, browbeat, overcome

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To be more attractive than (someone or something).
examples: Nobody’s equipage outlooked ours except my Lord Lieutenant’s, but in every respect I must say Mrs. Clayton outshines her neighbours [...]

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To inspect throughly; to select.
examples: Here’s a day that is worth a year’s wishing;
See that all things be right,
To want tools when a man goes a fishing.
[...] to fit minds to so even a temper, that both should round the same circle, and never out-look the Horizon of their reciprocal Interest, is a work altogether impossible.

description: From out +‎ look. Perhaps influenced by Chinese 外表 (literally “outside + surface”) and English look (“appearance”). Same etymology as Cantonese outlook.
